Hovey — 5
How, what this all adds up to, in terms of American-Italian
understanding I’m sure I don't know. As I suggested in a previous Letter,
some aspects of this cultural invasion may help to explain evidences of
anti-Americanism which some Americans say they find in Italy today. Other
aspects have surely contributed to better understanding.
Writing several years ago about the influx of American students
and artists and scholars into Italy, Professor Paolo Milano was confident
about the results. He said*
*A direct dialogue between Italian and American intellectuals has
begun, the comedy of errors is being slowly dispelled.* Dr. Milano thought
the time might be near when the Italian reader would be convinced that the
general level of American culture was not so low as he believed the American
"digest* magazines imply. And that, surely, would be a good thing.
fou won't believe it, but while I was writing this broadcast on
the American cultural Invasion of Italy, a young Italian walked under the
window of my apartment at the south edge of Rome, whistling the theme song
from the American motion picture, "High Noon.*
Graham Hovey, signing another radio Letter from Italy. This
program was recorded in the Home studios of Radio Italians for the National
Association of Educational Broadcasters — and this la the NAEB Network.
